Function Documentation

double_int aa_max ( struct AA *  aa_list_p)

Calculate the maximum value of an affine definition.

Add the absolute values of all coefficients and return this value as the maximum value of the affine definition. If the affine element list is uninitialized return a value of zero.

Parameters
[in]aa_list_ppointer to head of AA list
Returns
double_int maximum value

Definition at line 521 of file fxopt_affine.c.

522 {
523  struct AA *aa_elt_p;
524 
525  double_int constant, maxval, coeff;
526 
527  if (aa_list_p == NULL)
528  return double_int_zero; // flag for uninitialized
529 
530  maxval = double_int_zero;
531  constant = double_int_zero;
532  DL_FOREACH(aa_list_p, aa_elt_p) {
533  coeff = aa_elt_p->coeff;
534  if (aa_elt_p->id == 0)
535  constant = coeff;
536  else
537  if (double_int_negative_p(coeff))
538  maxval = double_int_sub(maxval, coeff);
539  else
540  maxval = double_int_add(maxval, coeff);
541  }
542  maxval = double_int_add(constant, maxval);
543  return maxval;
544 }

double_int aa_min ( struct AA *  aa_list_p)

Calculate the minimum value of an affine definition.

The minimum value of the affine definition is equal to the coefficient of the constant term minus the absolute values of all other coefficients. Return this value as the minimum value of the affine definition. If the affine element list is uninitialized return a value of zero.

Parameters
[in]aa_list_ppointer to head of AA list
Returns
double_int minimum value

int abs_tree_floor_log2 ( tree  int_const)

Calculate the floor of the log2 of an integer constant tree.

Takes the absolute value of the integer constant, then calculates the base 2 log of its value. Returns the floor of the log as an integer.

Parameters
[in]int_constinteger constant tree
Returns
integer

Definition at line 1792 of file fxopt_utils.c.

1793 {
1794  int prec;
1795  HOST_WIDE_INT high, low;
1796 
1797  STRIP_NOPS(int_const);
1798 
1799  prec = TYPE_PRECISION(TREE_TYPE(int_const));
1800  high = TREE_INT_CST_HIGH(int_const);
1801  low = TREE_INT_CST_LOW(int_const);
1802 
1803  if (tree_int_cst_sign_bit(int_const)) {
1804  high = -high;
1805  low = -low;
1806  }
1807 
1808  // First clear all bits that are beyond the type's precision in case we've
1809  // been sign extended.
1810 
1811  if (prec == 2 * HOST_BITS_PER_WIDE_INT);
1812  else if (prec > HOST_BITS_PER_WIDE_INT)
1813  high &= ~((HOST_WIDE_INT) (-1) << (prec - HOST_BITS_PER_WIDE_INT));
1814  else {
1815  high = 0;
1816  if (prec < HOST_BITS_PER_WIDE_INT)
1817  low &= ~((HOST_WIDE_INT) (-1) << prec);
1818  }
1819 
1820  return (high != 0 ? HOST_BITS_PER_WIDE_INT + floor_log2(high)
1821  : floor_log2(low));
1822 }
int abs_tree_log2 ( tree  int_const)

Calculate log2 of a power-of-2 integer constant tree.

Modified version of tree_log2() from tree.c, but works for positive and negative constants. If int_const equals 2^k or -(2^k), return k else return -1.

Parameters
[in]int_constpointer to tree of the integer constant
Returns
log base 2 of absolute value of constant

void add_var_format ( int  var_id)

Add a new variable to the SIF format hash.

Given the hash key for a variable, create a new hash table entry for the variable and initialize the structure elements.

Parameters
[in]var_idthe calculated unique hash key for the variable

Definition at line 105 of file fxopt_utils.c.

106 {
107  struct SIF *s;
108  int uid = KEY_TO_UID(var_id);
109  if (uid == 0)
110  return; // an affine error term, not a real variable
111 
112  vars++;
113  s = (struct SIF *) xmalloc(sizeof(struct SIF));
114  initialize_format(s);
115  s->id = var_id;
116  //
117  // Look for an existing format definition for this variable where the
118  // pass count is 0 and the array index is ignored. If found, copy the
119  // format information from that variable's format.
120  //
121  int declid = UID_IDX_TO_KEY(uid, NOT_AN_ARRAY);
122  if (var_id != declid) {

141 }

struct AA* affine_add ( struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
bool  add 
)

Add or subtract statement affine result processing.

AA elements that are unique to either operand 1 or operand 2 are simply copied to the result AA list. For variables that are found in both the AA lists of operands 1 and 2, the coefficients are added. If the operation to be performed is subtraction rather than addition, then the coefficient of operand 2 is negated first. If the affine definition of either operand is missing return a NULL pointer.

Note
Assumes that operands are already aligned (have the same binary point location). A warning is issued if this is not the case.
Parameters
[in]oprnd_frmtarray of SIF structs for the operands
[in]addboolean, true for addition false for subtraction
Returns
pointer to the new AA list, NULL if failed

Definition: fxopt_plugin.h:83
struct AA* affine_multiply ( struct AA *  aa1_list_p,
struct AA *  aa2_list_p 
)

Multiply affine definitions.

Determine (or estimate) the affine result of multiplying two affine definitions.

Multiplication can result in both affine and non-affine terms in the product's affine definition. The only source of affine product terms is multiplication by a constant, so the constant term in the affine list for each operand is multiplied by all of the terms in the other affine list and the resulting affine terms are collected by summing the coefficients of terms that have the same ID value (i.e. depend on the same variable).

If the same variable exists in the AA list of both multiplicands then we get a term for that variable squared. Since an affine definition cannot have a quadratic term then we create a new unique error term. However, since this is a squared term it can never be negative. We find the product of the coefficients and half of that product is added to the constant term in the product's affine definition while the other half is added to the coefficient of the unique error term for all squared variable terms.

In all other cases we have the product of two affine terms that depend on different variables. Such a product cannot be represented in affine form so it becomes a new uncorrelated error term. However, if the same two variables exist in the affine definitions for both multiplicands we will effectively have the same product term twice. In this special case we should cancel the two coefficient products before lumping the result into the uncorrelated error term. Note that since all of these error terms are uncorrelated we must sum the absolute values of the products of their coefficients to get a coefficient for the lumped error term.

Parameters
aa1_list_phead of AA linked list for first operand
aa2_list_phead of AA linked list for second operand
Returns
pointer to the product's AA list, NULL if failed

771 
772  if ((aa1_list_p == NULL) || (aa2_list_p == NULL))
773  return NULL;
774 
775  int new_bp = get_aa_bp(aa1_list_p) + get_aa_bp(aa2_list_p);
776 
777  double_int aa_err = double_int_zero;
778  DL_FOREACH(aa1_list_p, aa1_elt_p) {
779  DL_FOREACH(aa2_list_p, aa2_elt_p) {
780  double_int product = double_int_mul(aa1_elt_p->coeff, aa2_elt_p->coeff);
781  if (aa1_elt_p->id == 0) { // op1 constant term
782  res_elt_p = search_aa_var(result_p, aa2_elt_p->id);
783  if (NULL != res_elt_p)
784  res_elt_p->coeff = double_int_add(res_elt_p->coeff, product);
785  else
786  append_aa_var(&result_p, aa2_elt_p->id, product, new_bp);
787  } else if (aa2_elt_p->id == 0) { // op2 constant term
788  res_elt_p = search_aa_var(result_p, aa1_elt_p->id);
789  if (NULL != res_elt_p)
790  res_elt_p->coeff = double_int_add(res_elt_p->coeff, product);
791  else
792  append_aa_var(&result_p, aa1_elt_p->id, product, new_bp);
793  //
794  // This is an error term that must be positive because the input is
795  // squared. Add half of the coefficient to the 'center' term. Since
796  // this error is uncorrelated with other squared errors, the absolute
797  // value of half of the coefficient is added to a new error term.
798  //
799  } else if (aa1_elt_p->id == aa2_elt_p->id) {
800  product = double_int_rshift(product, 1, HOST_BITS_PER_DOUBLE_INT,
801  ARITH);
802  res_elt_p = search_aa_var(result_p, 0);
803  if (NULL == res_elt_p)
804  append_aa_var(&result_p, 0, product, new_bp);
805  else
806  res_elt_p->coeff = double_int_add(res_elt_p->coeff, product);
807  aa_err = double_int_add(aa_err, double_int_abs(product));
808  } else { // uncorrelated error term
809  //
810  // if this product will occur twice then allow cancellation
811  // divide the sum of the product terms by 2 since we will see it twice
812  //
813  struct AA *other1 = search_aa_var(aa2_list_p, aa1_elt_p->id);
814  struct AA *other2 = search_aa_var(aa1_list_p, aa2_elt_p->id);
815  if (other1 && other2) {
816  double_int otherp = double_int_mul(other1->coeff, other2->coeff);
817  product = double_int_abs(double_int_add(product, otherp));
818  product = double_int_rshift(product, 1, HOST_BITS_PER_DOUBLE_INT,
819  ARITH);
820  aa_err = double_int_add(aa_err, product);
821  } else {
822  aa_err = double_int_add(aa_err, double_int_abs(product));
823  }
824  }
825  }
826  }
827 
828  if (!double_int_zero_p(aa_err)) {
829  append_aa_var(&result_p, next_error_id++, aa_err, new_bp);
830  }
831  return result_p;
832 }

struct AA* affine_square ( struct AA *  op1)
void append_aa_var ( struct AA **  aa_list_p,
int  var_key,
double_int  coeff,
int  bp 
)

Add a term to an affine definition.

Create a new list element and populate it with the hash table key for the variable being added, its coefficient, and the binary point location for the coefficient. If the coefficient is zero then this term is simply discarded. Append the new element to the existing affine definition. An error occurs if the list pointer is NULL or an element with the same ID is already in the list. Warnings are printed if the coefficient is zero and the element is discarded or if it appears that the list has been deleted.

Parameters
[in]aa_list_ppointer to the AA list head pointer
[in]var_keyhash table ID for variable being added to list
[in]coeffdouble_int, the coefficient for variable being added
[in]bpint, binary point location for coefficient

struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
tree  oprnd_tree[] 
)

Process ARRAY_REF (array reference) statements.

In general, the format of the result is set to be the same as the format of the RHS operand, considering the array index.

Examples of GIMPLE statements processed by this function:

D.1989_16 = data[3];
x5_28 = *D.1985_27[5];
x2_133 = *D.2065_132[col_2];
Warning
Casts from unsigned to signed may be untested

[in,out]oprnd_frmtarray of SIF format structs for all operands
[in,out]oprnd_treearray of gcc trees for the operands

int ceil_log2_range ( struct SIF  op_fmt)

Calculate the ceiling of the binary log of the range.

Determines the total number of bits required to represent the range of a given SIF structure. Takes absolute value of min and max and ORs their double_int representations, then finds the left-most 1 bit.

Parameters

Definition: fxopt_plugin.h:29
void convert_real_var_to_integer ( tree  var)

Convert floating variables to integers.

This function changes only the type of the variable, not its value. In all cases we change the type of the innermost underlying variable but the type of a variable may be specified multiple places, depending on the kind of variable.

  • If the var is a function parameter, change the function's parameter type as well.
  • If the var is a pointer, change the pointer's type as well.
  • If the var is an array, also change the size of whole array and the size of each array element. The mode, constant, and public parameters for the array are configured.
Note
The specific integer type used to replace floating types is defined by REAL_TO_INTEGER_TYPE.
Parameters
[in,out]vargcc tree for a variable

struct SIF division ( gimple_stmt_iterator *  gsi_p,
struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
tree  oprnd_tree[] 
)

Integer division.

Determine what formatting is needed for the dividend and divisor before the divsion can be performed, and determine the format for the resulting format.

If the option for converting constant division to multiplication by the inverse is enabled, then just calculate the reciprocal of the constant, change the operation to multiplication, and call the function that processes multiplication statements.

If the divisor is a constant equal to an integer power of 2, then a virtual shift is performed. The binary point is moved as needed and the statement is converted to a NOP assignment.

Examples of GIMPLE statements processed by this function:

D.1977_4 = D.1976_3 / 4.096e+3;
D.1979_8 = D.1978_7 / 5.0e+0;
D.1983_11 = InVal_4(D) / D.1982_10;
Parameters
[in]gsi_pstatement iterator, points to statement being processed
[in,out]oprnd_frmtarray of SIF format structs for all operands
[in,out]oprnd_treearray of gcc trees for the operands
Returns
SIF format struct for the result

void force_ptr_consistency ( )

Force consistency of SIF formats for versions of pointers.

We assume that memory locations accessed via pointers will only be modified once, if at all, in any given GIMPLE basic block. At the end of each basic block we look for aliased variables and recompute the range for them by finding the widest range that would include the ranges of all aliases of the variable. At this point we've lost any valid affine definition so the variable is given a new affine definition that just specifies the range of the variable, without correlations to any input parameters.

483  // Expect the same binary point location
484  //
485  bp = s->F + s->E;
486  if (bp != (ss->F + ss->E))
487  fprintf(stderr, " Inconsistent binary point locations");
488 
489  ss->max = double_int_smax(s->max, ss->max);
490  ss->min = double_int_smin(s->min, ss->min);
491  aamax = double_int_smax(aa_max(ss->aa), aa_max(s->aa));
492  aamin = double_int_smin(aa_min(ss->aa), aa_min(s->aa));
493 
494  x0 = double_int_rshift(double_int_add(aamax, aamin), 1,
495  HOST_BITS_PER_DOUBLE_INT, ARITH);
496  x1 = double_int_rshift(double_int_sub(aamax, aamin), 1,
497  HOST_BITS_PER_DOUBLE_INT, ARITH);
498 
499  key = UID_PASS_IDX_TO_KEY(KEY_TO_UID(ss->id), fxpass, index);
500  delete_aa_list(&(ss->aa));
501  if (!double_int_zero_p(x0))
502  append_aa_var(&(ss->aa), 0, x0, bp);
503  if (!double_int_zero_p(x1))
504  append_aa_var(&(ss->aa), key, x1, bp);
505  s->alias = key;
506  } // found an aliased variable in this pass
507  } // all formats
508 
509  HASH_SORT(var_formats, id_sort);
510  uid = 0;
511  for (s = var_formats; s != 0; s = (struct SIF *) (s->hh.next)) {
512  //
513  // If the uid has changed and the saved uid is nonzero then we have
514  // been accumulating the min and max for the saved uid. Store them
515  // in the formats for every index of that uid in this pass
516  //
517  if ((0 != uid) && (KEY_TO_UID(s->id) != uid)) {
518  for (j = 0; j < MAX_ELEMENTS; j++) {
519  key = UID_PASS_IDX_TO_KEY(uid, fxpass, j);
520  HASH_FIND_INT(var_formats, &key, ss);
521  if (NULL != ss) {
522  ss->max = max;
523  ss->min = min;
524  x0 = double_int_rshift(double_int_add(aamax, aamin), 1,
525  HOST_BITS_PER_DOUBLE_INT, ARITH);
526  x1 = double_int_rshift(double_int_sub(aamax, aamin), 1,
527  HOST_BITS_PER_DOUBLE_INT, ARITH);
528  delete_aa_list(&(ss->aa));
529  if (!double_int_zero_p(x0))
530  append_aa_var(&(ss->aa), 0, x0, bp);
531  if (!double_int_zero_p(x1))
532  append_aa_var(&(ss->aa), key, x1, bp);
533  }
534  }
535  uid = 0;
536  max = double_int_zero;
537  min = double_int_zero;
538  aamax = double_int_zero;
539  aamin = double_int_zero;
540  }
541  //
542  // This variable is a pointer that we've already seen, in this pass
543  //
544  if ((KEY_TO_UID(s->id) == uid) && (KEY_TO_PASS(s->id) == fxpass)) {
545  if (NOT_AN_ARRAY != KEY_TO_IDX(s->id)) {
546  max = double_int_smax(max, s->max);
547  min = double_int_smin(min, s->min);
548  aamax = double_int_smax(aamax, aa_max(s->aa));
549  aamin = double_int_smin(aamin, aa_min(s->aa));
550  }
551  //
552  // Look for pointer variables that were modified in this pass
553  // Since the hash is sorted, this must be the lowest index
554  //
555  } else if ((s->ptr_op) && !(s->alias) && (KEY_TO_PASS(s->id) == fxpass)) {
556  uid = KEY_TO_UID(s->id);
557  max = s->max;
558  min = s->min;
559  aamax = aa_max(s->aa);
560  aamin = aa_min(s->aa);
561  bp = s->F + s->E;
562  }
563  }
564 }

1373  op_fmt.min = double_int_neg(op_fmt.max);
1374  op_fmt.max =
1375  double_int_lshift(op_fmt.max, op_fmt.E,
1376  HOST_BITS_PER_DOUBLE_INT, ARITH);
1377  op_fmt.min =
1378  double_int_lshift(op_fmt.min, op_fmt.E,
1379  HOST_BITS_PER_DOUBLE_INT, ARITH);
1380  }
1381  //
1382  // Turn off interval arithmetic (for experimental purposes)
1383  //
1384  if (!INTERVAL) {
1385  op_fmt.max = double_int_mask(op_fmt.I + op_fmt.F + op_fmt.E);
1386  op_fmt.min = double_int_neg(op_fmt.max);
1387  }
1388  //
1389  // Using affine range instead of interval arithmetic
1390  //
1391  if ((AFFINE) && (NULL != op_fmt.aa)) {
1392  op_fmt.max = aa_max(op_fmt.aa);
1393  op_fmt.min = aa_min(op_fmt.aa);
1394  }
1395 
1396  op_fmt.originalF = op_fmt.F;
1397  //
1398  // If desired, print the operand's format
1399  //
1400  if (print) {
1401  if (op_fmt.alias != 0) {
1402  fprintf(stderr, " OP%d @", op_number);
1403  } else if (op_fmt.ptr_op != 0) {
1404  fprintf(stderr, " OP%d *", op_number);
1405  } else {
1406  fprintf(stderr, " OP%d ", op_number);
1407  }
1408  if (op_fmt.iv)
1409  fprintf(stderr, "(%2d/%2d/--/--)", op_fmt.S, op_fmt.I);
1410  else
1411  fprintf(stderr, "(%2d/%2d/%2d/%2d)", op_fmt.S, op_fmt.I, op_fmt.F,
1412  op_fmt.E);
1413  if (op_fmt.sgnd) {
1414  fprintf(stderr, "s ");
1415  } else {
1416  fprintf(stderr, "u ");
1417  }
1418  if (AFFINE) {
1419  print_aa_list(op_fmt.aa);
1420  }
1421  if (INTERVAL)
1422  print_min_max(op_fmt);
1423  else
1424  fprintf(stderr, "\n");
1425  }
1426  } // found some kind of format to use
1427 
1428  return op_fmt;
1429 }

void initialize_format ( struct SIF *  s)

Initialize the SIF definition for a variable.

Most of the elements of the SIF structure are given default values. Setting the I and F elements to zero indicates that the SIFE values are undefined. Setting the max value to zero and the min value to one marks the range as undefined. Setting the aa to NULL indicates that the affine equation is undefined.

[in]spointer to SIF structure

struct SIF int_const_to_range ( tree  int_const,
struct SIF  result_frmt 
)
void int_constant_format ( tree  integer_cst,
struct SIF *  op_fmt_p 
)

Determine the fixed-point format for an integer constant.

The constant is assumed to be a true integer with no F or E bits. The number of I bits is determined by the magnitude of the integer unless the integer is exactly zero, then it gets an I value of 1. If the constant is negative the format is assumed to be signed with one sign bit, else the value of S is zero. The range min and max are set to the constant's value, as is the center element of the affine definition.

Note
Constant operands are not the same as variables and don't have a specified size in GIMPLE. The size used in the SIF format is just the value of I+S.
Parameters
[in]integer_cstgcc tree for the integer constant
[in,out]op_fmt_ppointer to SIF structure for the constant

int log2_range ( struct SIF  op_fmt)

Checks for a constant value range that is a power of 2.

If the input SIF represents a constant (op_fmt.max == op_fmt.min), then determine whether that constant is an integer power of 2. If so, return the log2 of the absolute value of the constant, else return -1. Note that this function examines the double_int value of the constant, which is an integer. There is no consideration of the actual binary point location.

This function checks the bitwise AND of const_val and const_val-1. If the result is all zeros, then const_val has a single bit set to 1

Parameters
[in]op_fmtSIF structure for a variable or constant
Returns
log2 of a constant
  • k if a constant equal to 2^k or -(2^k)
  • -1 otherwise

struct SIF multiplication ( gimple_stmt_iterator *  gsi_p,
struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
tree  oprnd_tree[] 
)

Process multiplication statements.

For multiplication...

Examples of GIMPLE statements processed by this function:

D.1977_4 = D.1976_3 * 2.44140625e-4;
D.1978_5 = c2_1 * InVal_4(D);
D.2022_75 = D.2021_74 * x0_38;
Parameters
[in]gsi_pstatement iterator, points to statement being processed
[in,out]oprnd_frmtarray of SIF format structs for all operands
[in,out]oprnd_treearray of gcc trees for the operands
Returns
SIF format struct for the result

Special case of operand is a constant == 2^K: Will cause a "virtual shift" of other RHS operand, moving binary point K bits to the right (K > 0) or left (K < 0).

If either operand is less than 1 (no I bits) and there are X known sign bits to the right of the binary point, then X integer bits in the result will actually be redundant sign bits. But X can't be greater than the number of integer bits in the other operand.

If the double precision multiply is enabled, double the operand sizes for the multiplication (unless the operands are so small that the result will fit in current size). This will cause the rhs operands to be cast to the wider type but there is no need to do any shifts to the operands.

Don't do a double-precision multiply if it provides no benefit (if the number of info bits in the product will fit in a single precision result). Note that the # of info bits in the operand formats may be larger than necessary if an operand has an fxfrmt attribute.

If there are so many integer bits that the product can't possibly fit in the LHS, we're hosed...can't even do double precision because we can't cast the result back to single

735  if (oprnd_frmt[2].F > 0) {
736  shift_right(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 2, 1);
737  } else if (oprnd_frmt[1].F > 0) { // no choice!
738  shift_right(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 1, 1);
739  }
740  }
741  } // while too many info bits
742 
743  if ((INFO_BITS(1) + INFO_BITS(2)) < result_info_bits) {
744  //
745  // Sometimes we get an unexpected empty bit when shifting
746  // a constant right. Give back an info bit.
747  //
748  fprintf(stderr, " *** Overoptimized, ");
749  if ((INFO_BITS(1) < INFO_BITS(2)) && (LOST_F_BITS(1) > 0)) {
750  fprintf(stderr, "shifting op1 left, info bits\n");
751  shift_left(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 1, 1);
752  } else if (LOST_F_BITS(2) > 0) {
753  fprintf(stderr, "shifting op2 left\n");
754  shift_left(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 2, 1);
755  } else if (LOST_F_BITS(1) > 0) {
756  fprintf(stderr, "shifting op1 left\n");
757  shift_left(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 1, 1);
758  } else {
759  fprintf(stderr, "no lost info bits to return\n");
760  }
761 
762  } // over optimized
763  } // operands must be shifted
764  //
765  // Product info bits will fit in result, but we may need to discard
766  // empty bits in the operands (i.e. right justify the operands).
767  // Start with the operand that has more empty bits.
768  //
769  while (((INFO_BITS(1) + oprnd_frmt[1].E +
770  INFO_BITS(2) + oprnd_frmt[2].E) > result_info_bits)
771  && (oprnd_frmt[1].E > 0 || oprnd_frmt[2].E > 0)) {
772  if (oprnd_frmt[1].E > oprnd_frmt[2].E) {
773  shift_right(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 1, oprnd_frmt[1].E);
774  } else {
775  shift_right(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 2, oprnd_frmt[2].E);
776  }
777  }
778  //
779  // Check if result could be invalid (most negative number)
780  //
781  int result_sign_bits =
782  result_frmt.size -
783  (oprnd_frmt[1].I + oprnd_frmt[2].I - fraction_zeros) -
784  (oprnd_frmt[1].F + oprnd_frmt[2].F) -
785  (oprnd_frmt[1].E + oprnd_frmt[2].E);
786  tmp_fmt = new_range_mul(oprnd_frmt, result_frmt);
787  if ((INTERVAL && max_is_mnn(tmp_fmt))
788  || ((!INTERVAL) && ROUNDING && (result_sign_bits == 1))) {
789  fprintf(stderr, " *** Adding a sign bit to prevent MNN *** \n");
790  if ((INFO_BITS(1) > INFO_BITS(2))
791  && ((oprnd_frmt[1].F + oprnd_frmt[1].E) > 0))
792  shift_right(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 1, 1);
793  else if ((oprnd_frmt[2].F + oprnd_frmt[2].E) > 0)
794  shift_right(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 2, 1);
795  else
796  fprintf(stderr, " *** FAILED to add a sign bit *** \n");
797  }
798  delete_aa_list(&(tmp_fmt.aa));
799  //
800  // Determine product format.
801  //
802  result_frmt.I = oprnd_frmt[1].I + oprnd_frmt[2].I - fraction_zeros;
803  result_frmt.F = oprnd_frmt[1].F + oprnd_frmt[2].F;
804  result_frmt.E = oprnd_frmt[1].E + oprnd_frmt[2].E;
805  result_frmt.S =
806  result_frmt.size - result_frmt.I - result_frmt.F - result_frmt.E;
807  if (result_frmt.S < result_frmt.sgnd)
808  error("fxopt: Multiplication FAILED, sign bit is lost");
809  //
810  // This can happen if the product is less than half the full
811  // scale result format range
812  //
813  tmp_fmt = new_range_mul(oprnd_frmt, result_frmt);
814  if ((pessimistic_format(tmp_fmt) >
815  fraction_zeros) && (result_frmt.I > 0)) {
816  fprintf(stderr, " *** Pessimistic multiplication axiom, ");
817  //
818  // Try to give back a fraction bit, but if impossible then convert
819  // an integer bit to a redundant sign bit
820  //
821  if ((INFO_BITS(1) < INFO_BITS(2)) && (oprnd_frmt[1].shift > 0)) {
822  fprintf(stderr, "shifting op1 left, info bits\n");
823  shift_left(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 1, 1);
824  result_frmt.F += 1;
825  } else if (oprnd_frmt[2].shift > 0) {
826  fprintf(stderr, "shifting op2 left\n");
827  shift_left(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 2, 1);
828  result_frmt.F += 1;
829  } else if (oprnd_frmt[1].shift > 0) {
830  fprintf(stderr, "shifting op1 left\n");
831  shift_left(oprnd_frmt, oprnd_tree, 1, 1);
832  result_frmt.F += 1;
833  } else {
834  fprintf(stderr, "converting I to S in result\n");
835  result_frmt.S += 1;
836  }
837  result_frmt.I -= 1;
838  }
839  delete_aa_list(&(tmp_fmt.aa));
840  tmp_fmt = new_range_mul(oprnd_frmt, result_frmt);
841  delete_aa_list(&(result_frmt.aa));
842  result_frmt = tmp_fmt; // shallow copy, don't delete tmp_fmt.aa
843  result_frmt.shift = 0;
844  } // not a multiply by 2^K
845  } // op2 format is initialized
846  } // op1 format is initialized
847  fix_aa_bp(result_frmt);
848  check_range(result_frmt);
849  return result_frmt;
850 }

struct AA* new_aa_list ( struct SIF  op_fmt)

Apply shift and round operations to an AA list.

A new AA list is created by applying a shift, and possibly a rounding operation, to the existing AA list in a operand's SIF structure. The size and direction of the shift is determined by the shift element value in the SIF structure, and the type of rounding is determined by the global option flags.

Todo:
Verify that the shift size and direction are valid with respect to the operand's format.

struct SIF new_range_add ( struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
struct SIF  result_frmt 
)

Determine the range for the result of addition.

Any pending shifts are applied to the operands. The maximum value of the result is the sum of the maximum values of the operands. The minimum value of the result is the sum of the minimum values of the operands. The returned SIF struct is a copy of the input result_frmt with the newly calculated range.

Parameters
[in]oprnd_frmt[]array of SIF format structs for the operands
[in]result_frmtthe original SIF format for the result value
Returns
SIF format struct for the result with updated range

struct SIF new_range_div ( struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
struct SIF  result_frmt 
)

Determine the range for the result of division.

Any pending shifts are applied to the operands, and they are sign-extended. If the range of the divisor includes zero then a divide-by-zero error is possible: warning message is send to stderr and the min/max values of the result are set to the limits of the result's format. If divide-by-zero is not possible, use a brute force approach and calculate the four possible results of dividing the min and max dividend by the min and max divisor. Select the min and max of these results for the min and max of the result.

The returned SIF struct is a copy of the input result_frmt with the newly calculated range.

Parameters
[in]oprnd_frmt[]array of SIF format structs for the operands
[in]result_frmtthe original SIF format for the result value
Returns
SIF format struct for the result with updated range

struct SIF new_range_mul ( struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
struct SIF  result_frmt 
)

Determine the range for the result of multiplication.

Any pending shifts are applied to the operands. A brute force approach: compute all four products of the min and max values of the two operands and select the minimum and maximum values of those products.

The returned SIF struct is a copy of the input result_frmt with the newly calculated range.

Definition: fxopt_range.c:220
struct SIF nop ( gimple_stmt_iterator *  gsi_p,
struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
tree  oprnd_tree[] 
)

Process unary assignment statements.

Includes NOP, NEGATE, truncation, casts, variable declarations, and simple assignments from a declared variable to an SSA name. If the size of operand[0] (the LHS) is different from the size of operand[1] (the RHS) then we have a problem...issue a gcc warning. In general, the format of the result is set to be the same as the format of the RHS operand. For memory loads and stores, the pointer is assigned the format of the data that it points to. For NEGATE instructions the minimum value of the result is set to the negative of operand[1]'s maximum, and vice-versa. When storing to memory try to preserve the location of the binary point. If the operands are an entire array, make the same changes to the SIF format structs for every element of the array.

Examples of GIMPLE statements processed in this function:

s1.11_58 = s1;
accum_20 = (float) D.1992_19;
*D.1985_78[0] = x6_63;
D.2004_53 = -s1.9_52;
*D.2104_204[col_2] = x4_185;
data[0] = InVal_4(D);
Warning
Casts from unsigned to signed may be untested
Parameters
[in]gsi_pstatement iterator, points to statement being processed
[in,out]oprnd_frmt[]array of SIF format structs for all operands
[in,out]oprnd_tree[]array of gcc trees for the operands
Returns
SIF format struct for the result

int pessimistic_format ( struct SIF  op_fmt)

Check a SIF format for excess integer bits.

Return false if the format has no integer bits or represents the constant zero. Otherwise, calculate the range of the format after applying any shifts, then determine how many integer bits are needed to represent it. If that value is less than the number of bits provided in the format then return true.

struct SIF pointer_math ( gimple_stmt_iterator *  gsi_p,
struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
tree  oprnd_tree[] 
)

Process statements that include pointer arithmetic.

Includes POINTER_PLUS_EXPR, which adds an offset to a pointer, and MEM_REF, which uses a pointer to access a memory location. The RHS will include a pointer and (possibly) an offset that must be added to the pointer.

In GIMPLE the pointer offset is always some number of bytes, regardless of the actual size of the pointee's data type. If the pointer is to a real type then we may need to modify the offset's value for the new size of the replacement real-to-integer type.

The LHS may be a pointer (POINTER_PLUS_EXPR) or a normal variable (MEM_REF)

Examples of GIMPLE statements processed by this function:

D.1985_27 = dctBlock_6(D) + D.1984_26;
D.2065_132 = dctBlock_6(D) + 128;
Parameters
[in]gsi_pstatement iterator, points to statement being processed
[in,out]oprnd_frmtarray of SIF format structs for all operands
[in,out]oprnd_treearray of gcc trees for the operands
Returns
SIF format struct for the result

Print a single affine list element to stderr.

Converts the coefficient to a floating-point value and prints it. Compare the ranges of two formats.

Apply any pending shift operations and then align the binary points of the min and max values. Compare the min and max values of the two ranges to see how range 1 compares to range 2.

Parameters
[in]fmt1SIF struct containing first range
[in]fmt2SIF struct containing second range
Returns
integer comparison result
  • +1 if range 1 is (at least) partially outside range 2
  • -1 if range 1 is inside range 2
  • 0 if range 1 and range 2 are equal

void real_expr_to_integer ( gimple  stmt)

Convert floating operations to integer operations.

There are some GIMPLE assignment operations that are defined only for floating-point operands, and for these operations the GIMPLE statement is modified to use an appropriate integer operation instead.

Note
Only the operation is modified, the operands are not affected.
This only works for binary expressions, for unary expressions the "rhs_code" is actually the code for operand 1, which gets fixed when we call get_operand_format.

Stores the calculated SIF format for an operand.

Given the tree for a statement LHS operand, set the format of the underlying declared variable.

Only the SIF-related parameters can be changed. These are the SIF structure elements for

struct AA* shift_aa_list ( struct SIF  op_fmt,
int  k 
)

Perform a virtual shift on an AA list.

Return an new AA list that is a copy of the op_fmt's list, except that each element has been effectively shifted left by k bits. Instead of shifting the coefficients, the binary point location is moved right. This is accomplished by subtracting k from the binary point location of each element and leaving the coefficients unchanged. Note that a virtual shift is equivalent to multiplication by 2^k, and that a negative value for k is a virtual right shift.

Todo:
Test k value. Must have (k <= (F+E)) and (k >= -I)
Parameters
[in]op_fmtSIF of the original, unshifted operand
[in]knumber of bit positions to shift
Returns
pointer to new AA list

void shift_left ( struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
tree  oprnd_tree[],
int  opnumber,
int  count 
)

Shift an SIF format left.

Discards sign bits. Keeps track of whether a bit "shifted in" at the LSB is an empty bit or a valid fraction bit. This can be important if we shift something right and then shift it back left.

Parameters
[in]oprnd_frmtoperand SIF structure array
[in]oprnd_treeoperand tree array
[in]opnumberoperand number to be shifted
[in]countnumber of positions to shift

void shift_right ( struct SIF  oprnd_frmt[],
tree  oprnd_tree[],
int  opnumber,
int  count 
)

Perform a right shift on an SIF format.

Adds sign bits on the left and discards fraction and empty bits Don't actually shift the operand, just modify the format to what it would be after the shift and keep track of the cumulative shifts If the operand is a constant, determine the true number of empty bits in the shifted and rounded value.

Parameters
[in]oprnd_frmtoperand SIF structure array
[in]oprnd_treeoperand tree array
[in]opnumberoperand number to be shifted
[in]countnumber of positions to shift
